urn:contentItem:5NBW-FF71-F0J6-J512-00000-00About 120 burns planned for Victoria2017-04-20T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:27:49ZLexisNexisAbout 120 burns planned for Victoria

RELATED:

EXPECT to see and smell smoke for the next few days, with about 120 fuel reduction burns scheduled for ignition statewide between now and Friday.

Stable conditions have prompted Forest Fire Management Victoria to conduct more planned burns, Deputy Chief Fire Officer Darrin McKenzie said.

"As the weather starts to get cooler we need to take every opportunity to reduce bushfire risk for our communities next year by conducting these planned burns," he said.

Forest Fire Management Victoria is working in partnership with the Country Fire Authority to conduct the burns.

Mr McKenzie said the planned burning would result in smoke being seen across regional Victoria.

He cautioned that some parks and forests might be closed.

Planned burns might also affect visibility on roads and might result in traffic management measures, including speed restrictions and road closures.

"We understand that smoke from planned burning as well as smoke from private burn-offs can affect some people and appreciate everyone's patience while we complete this work," Mr McKenzie said

He said people could check if any smoke they encountered was the result of a planned burn by checking the website: www.ffm.vic.gov.au/plannedburn

Information is also available via the VicEmergency app or by calling the VicEmergency hotline on 1800 226 226.

The Department of Health and Human Services advises people experiencing symptoms that might be related to smoke exposure to seek medical advice or call Nurse-on-Call on 1300 60 60 24

urn:contentItem:5V50-YCP1-F0J6-J1WB-00000-00Planned burn at Apsley common2019-01-09T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:27:49ZLexisNexisPlanned burn at Apsley commonAlexander Darling

Residents in the Wimmera's far west can expect to see or smell smoke from Wednesday afternoon, when a planned burn takes place at Apsley common.

Forest Fire Management Victoria and the Country Fire Authority will undertake the nine-hectare backburn near Banayeo Road, Apsley-Natimuk Road, Dixon and Ballantyne streets from 1pm until 6pm from Wednesday until the following Wednesday, January 16.

Forest Fire Management Victoria Wimmera district manager Glenn Rudolph said planned burns had been carried out on the Common for a number of years.

The CFA are also planning to carry out a 25-hectare burn at the Apsley racecourse on Wednesday night.

The strategy forms part of ongoing efforts to protect the town from grass fires.

"CFA may also undertake some roadside burning," Mr Rudolph said.

"Signs may be in placed to slow traffic. Obey all traffic signs and instructions from fire agency crews near the burn.

"The aim of the planned burn is to reduce grass fuels on the Common. Grass fuels need to be sufficiently dry for the burn to take place, which requires the burn be carried out in summer if conditions are suitable.

"Travellers on the Wimmera Highway and Apsley-Natimuk Road may see or smell smoke, however there are no planned road closures at this time. A south-westerly wind is forecast, so wind is expected to take smoke away from the surrounding houses."

Mr Rudolph said people wanting the latest information on planned burns could go to ffm.vic.gov.au/plannedburn, download the VicEmergency app or call the VicEmergency hotline on 1800 226 226.

The CFA's Wimmera division has also produced a set of guidelines for the benefit of residents who might want help fighting fires with their private equipment.

District 17 operations manager Craig Brittain said the guidelines could be found at District 17's office in McLachlan Street, Horsham.

He said the guidelines could provide people with information about setting up their equipment for safe use, and how to operate on the fireground.

"Private equipment may include slip-on units, water trailers and water tankers that are appropriately set up for firefighting, along with farm machinery and heavy plant," he said.

"When you arrive on scene, present yourself to the nearest fire tanker or command vehicle, usually marked CFA with lights and sirens, and take instruction from the CFA member in charge. We ask that you work co-operatively with CFA crews to ensure your own safety and effective firefighting.

"Be aware of the situation around you and any hazards likely to cause harm. Be particularly careful about vehicles moving in poor visibility and hazardous trees which may fall without warning.

"It's really important to wear appropriate personal protective clothing and safety gear, such as long trousers, work boots, long sleeves, gloves, goggles, a helmet and a face mask to protect you from smoke inhalation."

urn:contentItem:5XJT-NSJ1-JD34-V3B8-00000-0030 fires sparked by lightning strikes2019-11-23T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:27:49ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 330 fires sparked by lightning strikesBlair Thomson

Crews are continuing to battle forest fires caused by lightning strikes in the North East, with 30 incidents sparked on Thursday night.

Firefighters responded to incidents in Yackandandah, Big Ben, Gundowring, Sandy Creek and the Tallangatta Valley.

Multiple fires were burning in remote land between Mitta and Tawonga.

150 firefighters had contained 10 fires by yesterday afternoon with support from water bombing aircraft.

There were five fires burning in steep, difficult terrain, with containment lines being created ahead of worsening conditions on Monday.

None of the incidents have threatened properties, but authorities issued warnings and urged residents to monitor conditions.

It followed a 200-hectare blaze at Coreen on Thursday.

Forest Fire Management Victoria spokesman Aaron Kennedy said the fires were up to 17 hectares in size.

"We're aggressively hitting these fires with aircraft, including large air tankers from Canberra and Sydney," he said.

"We've also deployed rappel crews to remote areas, where it's difficult for ground crews and machinery to access."

The rappel crews are lowered from helicopters into forest to tackle the fires.

"All of the fires are in quite remote areas," Mr Kennedy said.

"They might be visible for communities but none pose a threat to life or property at this point in time.

"We ask people to keep updated by keeping a listen to emergency broadcasts, or going to the VicEmergency website or downloading the app."

urn:contentItem:5XJC-N231-JBF5-T0JS-00000-00Meet the Victorian timber workers who aren't ready to leave the industry2019-11-21T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:27:49ZLexisNexisMeet the Victorian timber workers who aren't ready to leave the industryBy state political reporter Richard Willingham

Timber is in Denise Broxam's blood. Her father owned and ran a mill in Warburton, east of Melbourne, and at 16 she left school to work there.

She now runs the business in Gladysdale, a tiny town on the banks of the Little Yarra River.

Like many in small towns who rely heavily on timber to keep their communities afloat, Ms Broxam feels sick about the end of native timber logging.

There are also emerging warnings from the industry that the closure will hurt the state's ability to fight bushfires.

Two weeks ago, Premier Daniel Andrews announced plans to end native logging in the state by 2030, with reductions in timber supply from state-owned forests to start from 2024.

"It's devastating for all our workers. I'm worried for our staff and I'm worried for our community,'' Ms Broxam says.

"We are not ready to go - I want to be in this industry, I've been in this industry my whole life."

The Government is "stepping down" the industry because it says the sustainable supply of native timber is running out due to over-logging, bushfire damage and native species protection.

The policy has left workers like 37-year-old Chris McDonald in limbo.

"It's pretty worrying. [I'm] looking at getting a house loan," he says.

"And [I'm] not really sure of where to go and what to do.

"I'm not sure whether it's worth staying around this district because there's not much employment around here without the sawmills."

Firefighting skills at risk, loggers say

When bushfires strike, loggers in Victoria's central highlands stop chopping and take their heavy machinery to the fire front.

They use excavators and bulldozers to build fire breaks, cut tracks for fire trucks and suppress fires.

They are a critical cog in the firefighting machine.

But loggers say this valuable skill set will be lost once logging is banned.

"You need dozers to create new fire trails, you need dozers to help with your backburns," said Powelltown harvester Gary Moran, who has been involved in fighting every major local fire in recent decades.

"They are your first attack vehicles, they are the big strong solid machines. They can take the whack [of a fire].''

He and his colleagues spend their lives in the bush and believe they know best how to fight fires there.

"You take us out of it - who is going to be about to do it?" he asked.

"You can pull a dozer off Eastlink or pull a dozer off here or a dozer off there, but you need the tractor drivers, you need dozer drivers that know how to work in the bush."

As part of the transition plans, forestry workers will be encouraged to join the forest fire management sector.

A spokesman for the Government said the forestry transition to plantation timber would not have an impact on the state's ability to respond to bushfires.

"We'll continue to grow skills within the FFM [Forest Fire Management] Vic workforce and retain access to the important equipment required for forest firefighting,'' the spokesman said.

Mill owner hopes public opinion can save industry

Harold Fox's mill employs 30 people in Powelltown, a town of about 200.

He has been in the trade since 1976 and says he is deeply worried about his business when the major reduction of supply occurs in 2024.

But there are warnings from some within the sector and from environment groups that there is not even enough timber to last until 2024.

Reduced availability is a major reason for the Government's policy.

But Mr Fox argues there would be ample supply if protections on some land were lifted.

He says too many people misunderstand how sustainable forestry can be.

"I'm hoping by 2030 enough people will realise that this is sustainable and maybe we will harvest more after 2030: it depends on the public appetite," he says.

The Government said there would be a competitive tender process for the reduced supply from 2024 and there would also be an independent audit of this process.

urn:contentItem:5N4G-CSK1-F0JP-W42D-00000-00Trail blazers warned off2017-03-21T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:27:49ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 11Trail blazers warned offALEX SINNOTT

BRAZEN cyclists are riding into the line of fire with the state's forest management warning of upcoming planned burns.

Forest Fire Management Victoria (FFMV) claims dozens of cyclists broke into restricted areas last planned burn season in several locations along the Surf Coast and at Forrest.

FFMV fuel management officer Bodin Campbell said the restricted areas were clearly sign posted but some cyclists had ignored warnings.

"These incidents took place after the ignition when there were numerous smouldering tree stumps and hazardous trees which could have fallen down or dropped limbs," he said.

"It was extremely fortunate that riders were not injured as they ignored signage and entered taped off areas." Mr Campbell said dozens of members of the public were seen riding through closed mountain bike trails within burn areas during a series of planned burns near Anglesea last spring.

"In the coming weeks, a number of local mountain bike trails will be closed during planned burning operations, and we're pleading with riders to use common sense," he said.

"If riders travel through areas that are out of bounds, they not only risk their safety but the safety of emergency crews who may be called to rescue them.""For the safety of riders and Forest Fire Management Victoria crews, a large section of the popular Hurst Rd Trails at Anglesea will be closed, as well as other trails at Forrest, Anglesea, Aireys Inlet and Lorne."

urn:contentItem:5M2V-6HV1-JD34-V236-00000-00Fire season mows ahead in the region2016-11-02T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:27:49ZLexisNexisNEWSFire season mows ahead in the regionMark Kearney

More than 1000 hectares of public land in central Victoria is about to be slashed in preparation for what experts are calling a high-risk fire season this summer.

Forest Fire Management Victoria will cut grass in many areas, including Maryborough.

Above-average rainfall in the region during 2016 has not only delayed maintenance work, but has also encouraged vegetation growth that could prove dangerous as the weather warms.

FFMV regional director Paul Bates said privately-owned land was also at risk of bushfire and implored homeowners to regularly cut grass and clear their yards of leaves.

"Reducing bushfire risk is a shared responsibility," Mr Bates said.

"Reducing fuel loads on public land can only do so much - communities and households need to know how to be prepared and reduce their bushfire risk on their property."

The warnings follow a similar message from the Victorian Emergency Management Commissioner, Craig Lapsley, last week.

Authorities are also reminding holidaymakers this long weekend about fire safety.

Fires should also be entirely extinguished with water, not soil, and all rubbish should be taken out of campsites, a Forest Fire Management Victoria spokesperson said.

People concerned about long grass in their neighbourhood, or who see suspicious behaviour on public land, should phone Department of Environment, Land, Water and Planning on 136 186.

urn:contentItem:5M44-1SP1-JD34-V3VF-00000-00Fire Awareness Awards finalists announced2016-11-08T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:27:49ZLexisNexisFire Awareness Awards finalists announcedSiobhan Calafiore

Three organisations within the Ballarat district have been announced as finalists for the Fire Awareness Awards.

Maryborough Education Centre received the nod for Emergency Services Journey, Scotsburn Community Recovery Committee for Strengthening Communities After the Scotsburn Fires and Clunes Fire Brigade for This Week's Job.

The community focused awards, run by MFB, CFA and Forest Fire Management Victoria, acknowledge groups and organisations that deliver projects aimed at reducing the incidence and impact of fire.

The projects can focus on any type of fire, including structure fires, bushfires and grass fires.

Forest Fire Management Victoria chief fire officer Stephanie Rotarangi said the awards acknowledged the efforts community groups and industry members put into helping protect their communities.

"The quality of this year's entries was outstanding, demonstrating that Victorians understand the importance of fire awareness and safety," she said.

The finalists will be acknowledged at a ceremony in Melbourne next month.

RACV Insurance will award the RACV Insurance Award for Excellence, which is worth $10,000, to the most outstanding application.

There will also be three special incentive grants of up to $2000 available to assist individuals, community groups, schools, volunteers or not-for-profit organisations to undertake a new fire project or further develop an existing fire project.

urn:contentItem:5M2V-6HV1-JD34-V21F-00000-00Fire season mows ahead in the region2016-11-02T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:27:49ZLexisNexisFire season mows ahead in the regionMark Kearney

More than 1000 hectares of public land in central Victoria is about to be slashed in preparation for what experts are calling a high-risk fire season this summer.

Forest Fire Management Victoria will cut grass in many areas, including Maryborough.

Above-average rainfall in the region during 2016 has not only delayed maintenance work, but has also encouraged vegetation growth that could prove dangerous as the weather warms.

FFMV regional director Paul Bates said privately-owned land was also at risk of bushfire and implored homeowners to regularly cut grass and clear their yards of leaves.

"Reducing bushfire risk is a shared responsibility," Mr Bates said.

"Reducing fuel loads on public land can only do so much - communities and households need to know how to be prepared and reduce their bushfire risk on their property."

The warnings follow a similar message from the Victorian Emergency Management Commissioner, Craig Lapsley, last week.

Authorities are also reminding holidaymakers this long weekend about fire safety.

Fires should also be entirely extinguished with water, not soil, and all rubbish should be taken out of campsites, a Forest Fire Management Victoria spokesperson said.

People concerned about long grass in their neighbourhood, or who see suspicious behaviour on public land, should phone Department of Environment, Land, Water and Planning on 136 186.

urn:contentItem:5MNT-Y0J1-F0J6-J1D1-00000-00Grass slashing starts after rain delay2016-10-19T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:27:49ZLexisNexisGrass slashing starts after rain delaySophie Boyd

AFTER a delayed start to the grass slashing season, Forest Fire Management Victoria crews are preparing to start their grass slashing program.

Forest Fire Management Victoria Wimmera District Manager Russell Manning said the program was delayed due to heavy rain and access difficulties at sites.

He said after community consultation, crews would focus on public land around Stawell, Dimboola, Natimuk, Cavendish and Ararat.

Mr Manning said grass slashing was a vital part of fire prevention.

"Planned burning is not the only fuel management activity that we undertake," he said.

"Strategic mechanical treatments such as slashing and mowing are part of our summer fire preparation plan and are a necessary non-burning fuel reduction technique in and around towns."

Mr Manning said the heavy rain had encouraged grass growth.

"With recent heavy rain across the district, however, there is high likelihood that many areas may need to be slashed again later in the year," he said.

"Slashing and mowing also promotes growth of native grasses, which helps to protect native vegetation stands along creeks and rivers.

"The weather has inevitably shortened the opportunity for spring burning, however, a number of strategic burns are still planned for the Wimmera in the coming weeks.

"In addition, field preparation for the Autumn fuel management program has already begun across the region".

urn:contentItem:5PV4-T6P1-JD34-V3VC-00000-00Emergency services prepare for season ahead2017-10-19T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:27:49ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 4Emergency services prepare for season aheadAshley Fritsch

Fire, storms and natural hazards were the topic of conversation as central Victoria's emergency services joined forces for a pre-summer season briefing.

Incident management teams from Forest Fire Management Victoria, the Department of Environment, Land, Water and Planning, Country Fire Authority, State Emergency Service, Victoria Police and Department of Health & Human Services met on Tuesday to prepare for the season ahead.

FFMVic Loddon Mallee regional controller Rob Price said the preparations were not just about fire, with the region facing floods at this time last year.

"We know that while we're focusing on fire, the emergency response agencies have to be prepared for things like storm events, wind events and potentially for this year, heat events," he said. "Our incident management teams are getting updated information on our protocols, new directions and arrangements and how we support our people on the ground that are actually responding to the incident."

For the season ahead, CFA regional commander Scott Purdy said a dry winter had meant less grass growth than last year, but the bush was still extremely dry.

"This coming season presents the same sorts of challenges as we've had previously," he said. "We know the bush is drier, we know to expect a long, hot summer; we also know that we need to prepare for the onset of storms and other types of natural hazard events.

"In many ways we are preparing like we always do and urge the community to do the same."

The fire danger period has already commenced in parts of eastern Victoria and Mr Purdy said central Victoria's season would most likely begin with the Mallee region at the end of October, and then cascade down from there.

Forest Fire Management Victoria began its spring planned burning program on Tuesday and hopes to complete 12 burns across the region, weather permitting.

urn:contentItem:5VJV-P281-F031-X27C-00000-00Winery owner who 'begged' for fuel reduction burns loses everything in Bunyip fire2019-03-05T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:27:49ZLexisNexisWinery owner who 'begged' for fuel reduction burns loses everything in Bunyip fireBy Damian McIver and Isabella Pittaway

The owner of a Tonimbuk winery destroyed by bushfire said his property might have been spared if only the Victorian Government had pursued a more active fuel reduction policy.

Andrew Clarke, the owner of the Jinks Creek Winery, was left devastated after the blaze ripped through his vineyard, cellar door, restaurant and adjoining house over the weekend.

"I don't have a livelihood," he told the ABC's Country Hour.

"I turn 60 this year and I've worked on the land all my life and I really don't think I've got it in me to replant my vineyard."

Mr Clarke is convinced the fire, which wassparked by dry lightning strikes in the Bunyip State Park last week, was exacerbated by the dense bushland that had been left to flourish behind his property.

"I've been begging them [Forest Fire Management Victoria] for 20 years to burn off the state forest at the back of our place and still to this day it hasn't happened," he said.

"I honestly believe the ferocity of that fire was fuelled by the trash in the bush - I think my place might not have been impacted nearly as much, it would have been much more controllable if there'd been some forest management out there."

Victorian Emergency Management Commissioner Andrew Crisp said it was not clear if planned burns would have helped.

"Planned burns aren't necessarily the panacea in relation to fires like this and you have to remember also that we've had record low rainfalls in many parts of the state, particularly in relation to Gippsland and these areas," he told ABC Radio Melbourne.

"At this particular point in time my focus is on the fact that we've still got active fires ... as will always be the case, there will be debriefs after this, but for now it's still about protecting life."

The Bushfire Royal Commission in 2010 recommended that 5 per cent of Victorian public land be burnt each year - up from less than 2 per cent before Black Saturday.

In 2012, the State Government dumped that target in favour of more focused burn-offs closer to communities, and alternative methods like slashing.

The amount of public land being burnt off has plummeted - from 185,000 hectares in 2015-16 to 65,000 hectares last year.

The former chief fire officer with the then Department of Sustainability and Environment, Ewan Waller, said the strategy was clearly failing.

"There's no doubt we've got to burn more," he said.

"Fuel is probably the only manageable element we can work on - we've got these dry seasons and windy days and hot searing heat, but fuel is something we can manage."

Specialist team needed to manage burns: Waller

Mr Waller said Forest Fire Management Victoria is understandably risk-averse, particularly after the Lancefield bushfire in 2015 when a planned burn-off escaped containment lines and destroyed four homes.

"Once you've got the politics involved and irate communities and the blame game ... we've got to get over that, we've got to protect the people doing the burning, they're taking on a heck of responsibility on behalf of the community and the Government," Mr Waller said.

Mr Waller acknowledged increasingly volatile weather had made fuel reduction burning "a very difficult proposition".

But he said extending the burning season could be one part of the solution.

"Normally the matches are put away at the end of Easter, we could look at burning into winter far more," he said.

He also suggested a specialist unit be established to manage burns.

"Maybe teams that are really tuned in that work around the state, doing nothing else but burn, they could be plotting and planning how to do the burning now," he said.

'No planned burn would have made a difference': Minister

State Opposition Leader Michael O'Brien said the Government had questions to answer.

"Has the Government dropped the ball when it comes to planned burns and if so, has this made these fires worse than they should have been?" he asked.

Premier Daniel Andrews defended his Government's policy and said he was advised there had been extensive backburning around the Bunyip State Forest, where conditions allowed.

"Ultimately this is always a really difficult balance and we take the advice of our experts ... they can only do backburning when it's safe to do so and part of the extraordinarily dry conditions that we have at the moment means it's very difficult to do that backburning," he said.

"The strength of the fires we've seen over the last few days means that that fire either went through or went over the firebreaks that have been built over the last couple of years."

Emergency Services Minister Lisa Neville said burning off would not have stopped the Bunyip fire.

"The intensity of this fire was enormous - no planned burn would have made a difference here," she said.

Ms Neville conceded that increasingly dry seasons would make it more difficult to do controlled burns.

Forest Fire Management Victoria was contacted for comment.

urn:contentItem:5TC2-4PK1-JD34-V2RM-00000-00Fire prevention preparation well underway across the Wimmera | News Focus2018-09-28T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:27:49ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 5Fire prevention preparation well underway across the Wimmera | News FocusPRU SAIMOUN

RELATED: Fire season could start up to a month early

RELATED: Fire fight is constant - just different - for Horsham urban firefighters

Forest Fire Management Victoria has been busy for weeks.

FFMVic Grampians Regional Assistant Chief Fire Officer, Grant Allan said the Bureau of Meteorology had forecast a longer, drier summer for Victoria, with an 'El Nino - Watch' in the current outlook.

"In response to this outlook, we have brought forward several preparedness activities, including our planned burn and slashing program," he said.

"The program creates fuel breaks, referred to as Asset Protection Zones, between public forest and private property to provide a permanent reduced fuel area.

"This allows for greater defendable spaces for these communities in the event of a significant bushfire.

"In addition, FFMVs seasonal contracted firefighters have been brought on four weeks earlier than previous years.

"This increased capability and capacity will assist crews with work ahead of the fire season, including spring planned burns, slashing, mulching and preparatory works."

Liaison with the CFA and SES on response plans and personnel rosters is up to date, Incident Control Centre auditing and joint exercises have been completed, airbases, helipads and fire lookouts are ready, all equipment and plant including tankers, dozers and radios have been checked and tested, and there have also been strategic road and firebreak network checks to ensure they are open and useable.

The Wimmera District Level three pre-season briefing will be on October 16.

Planned burning to reduce risk was completed in the Grampians and Little Desert National Parks near Dimboola in late winter and early spring, but further opportunities could be limited from now due to the expected early fire season start. Slashing and mulching of blocks close to towns, on forest boundaries and along strategic roadsides will now be the focus.

Residual risk in the South-West Bushfire Risk Landscape (SWBRL) is at 55 per cent - a slight increase from the last year, but below the 80 per cent target. The SWBRL extends south to Heywood and Portland, which are not within Forest Fire Management Victoria's Wimmera District, but which contribute to the bushfire risk.

Burns and other works are planned in 2018-19 to protect communities including Edenhope, Harrow, Ararat, Stawell, Dunkeld, Halls Gap and Pomonal.

Wimmera District could see five extra Project Fire Fighters this season; potentially two at Halls Gap, two at Horsham and one at Cavendish, with training and accreditation of new PFFs in late October.

For more information on planned burns go to www.ffm.vic.gov.au/ or for fire or preparation details go to   www.cfa.vic.gov.au

FFMVic Loddon Mallee regional controller Rob Price said the preparations were not just about fire, with the region facing floods at this time last year.

"We know that while we're focusing on fire, the emergency response agencies have to be prepared for things like storm events, wind events and potentially for this year, heat events," he said. "Our incident management teams are getting updated information on our protocols, new directions and arrangements and how we support our people on the ground that are actually responding to the incident."

For the season ahead, CFA regional commander Scott Purdy said a dry winter had meant less grass growth than last year, but the bush was still extremely dry.

"This coming season presents the same sorts of challenges as we've had previously," he said. "We know the bush is drier, we know to expect a long, hot summer; we also know that we need to prepare for the onset of storms and other types of natural hazard events.

"In many ways we are preparing like we always do and urge the community to do the same."

The fire danger period has already commenced in parts of eastern Victoria and Mr Purdy said central Victoria's season would most likely begin with the Mallee region at the end of October, and then cascade down from there.

Forest Fire Management Victoria began its spring planned burning program on Tuesday and hopes to complete 12 burns across the region, weather permitting.

urn:contentItem:5TC2-4PK1-JD34-V2PP-00000-00Fire prevention preparation well underway across the Wimmera | News Focus2018-09-28T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:27:49ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 5Fire prevention preparation well underway across the Wimmera | News FocusPRU SAIMOUN

RELATED: Fire season could start up to a month early

RELATED: Fire fight is constant - just different - for Horsham urban firefighters

Forest Fire Management Victoria has been busy for weeks.

FFMVic Grampians Regional Assistant Chief Fire Officer, Grant Allan said the Bureau of Meteorology had forecast a longer, drier summer for Victoria, with an 'El Nino - Watch' in the current outlook.

"In response to this outlook, we have brought forward several preparedness activities, including our planned burn and slashing program," he said.

"The program creates fuel breaks, referred to as Asset Protection Zones, between public forest and private property to provide a permanent reduced fuel area.

"This allows for greater defendable spaces for these communities in the event of a significant bushfire.

"In addition, FFMVs seasonal contracted firefighters have been brought on four weeks earlier than previous years.

"This increased capability and capacity will assist crews with work ahead of the fire season, including spring planned burns, slashing, mulching and preparatory works."

Liaison with the CFA and SES on response plans and personnel rosters is up to date, Incident Control Centre auditing and joint exercises have been completed, airbases, helipads and fire lookouts are ready, all equipment and plant including tankers, dozers and radios have been checked and tested, and there have also been strategic road and firebreak network checks to ensure they are open and useable.

The Wimmera District Level three pre-season briefing will be on October 16.

Planned burning to reduce risk was completed in the Grampians and Little Desert National Parks near Dimboola in late winter and early spring, but further opportunities could be limited from now due to the expected early fire season start. Slashing and mulching of blocks close to towns, on forest boundaries and along strategic roadsides will now be the focus.

Residual risk in the South-West Bushfire Risk Landscape (SWBRL) is at 55 per cent - a slight increase from the last year, but below the 80 per cent target. The SWBRL extends south to Heywood and Portland, which are not within Forest Fire Management Victoria's Wimmera District, but which contribute to the bushfire risk.

Burns and other works are planned in 2018-19 to protect communities including Edenhope, Harrow, Ararat, Stawell, Dunkeld, Halls Gap and Pomonal.

Wimmera District could see five extra Project Fire Fighters this season; potentially two at Halls Gap, two at Horsham and one at Cavendish, with training and accreditation of new PFFs in late October.

For more information on planned burns go to www.ffm.vic.gov.au/ or for fire or preparation details go to   www.cfa.vic.gov.au

urn:contentItem:5VTS-J6V1-F0J6-J1MR-00000-00Fire east of Kyneton brought under control2019-04-07T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:27:49ZLexisNexisFire east of Kyneton brought under control

Update, 6.20pm: FIREFIGHTERS have brought a slow burning bushfire on top of a hill in stringybark forest at Baynton under control.

CFA commander Chris Jacobsen said units would remain at the scene into the evening to ensure the fire was contained, ahead of forecast strong winds tomorrow.

He said the fire was never travelling far, but was in inaccessible terrain.

Eighteen CFA resources remain at the scene. Mr Jacobsen said DELWP also responded, with eight units.

Three aircraft joined the firefighting effort, including two fire bombing units and a supervisory aircraft.

Mr Jacobsen said about five hectares of private land was burnt.

"There was a lightning strike in the immediate vicinity last night," the CFA commander said.

A Forest Fire Management Victoria dozer will be used to create a bare earth break around the fire.

Mr Jacobsen said firefighters would then work in from there to make the fire safe.

He said limited access for large fire trucks in the densely vegetated area also contributed to the number of units deployed.

About 14 smaller firefighting vehicles, known within the CFA as slip-ons, were utilised because they were better able to manoeuvre between the trees.

Mr Jacobsen said Forest Fire Management Victoria worked well alongside CFA to bring the fire under control.

Given the windy weather conditions predicted for tomorrow, particularly in the morning, he urged people not to light fires outside of the fire danger period restrictions.

Summer might be over, but Mr Jacobsen reminded people the fire danger period was not.

He said it was still too dry for people to take any risks and urged anyone unfamiliar with the restrictions to visit the CFA website.

Click here to read the restrictions during the fire danger period.

Update, 4.40pm: COMMUNITIES nearby a bushfire at Baynton have been advised to stay informed and monitor conditions as firefighters respond.

"There is currently no threat to you," advice issued by the Country Fire Authority states.

"There is a slow-moving bushfire at Youngs Road, Baynton, that is not yet under control.

"The bushfire is travelling in a southerly direction.

"Firefighters from CFA and the Department of Environment, Land, Water and Planning are on scene."

Baynton, Baynton East, Benloch, Glenhope, Glenhope East, Lancefield, Nulla Vale and Pastoria East residents were advised smoke would be visible from nearby communities and roads.

The CFA said people should monitor warnings so they could act quickly if the situation changed, and monitor changes to the situation.

"Increased wind speed, change in wind direction, smoke or poor visibility can indicate the situation is changing," the advice message stated.

The CFA also issued the following information:

If you can smell smoke, please note:

Health information:

Update, 4.24pm: FURTHER support from aerial and ground crews has been requested as firefighters respond to a fire at Baynton, east of Kyneton.

Firefighters received reports of a column of smoke issuing from Youngs Road about 3.15pm.

The fire is in a fairly densely vegetated area.

Six Country Fire Authority trucks are on scene. The fire is not yet under control.

EARLIER: FIREFIGHTERS are responding to reports of a fire east of Kyneton, which is not yet under control.

Eight vehicles are believed to be responding to the blaze at Youngs Road in Baynton.

The fire is believed to have started about 3.15pm.

More to come.

urn:contentItem:5XB6-0VF1-F0JP-W2TT-00000-00Push for properties to be fire ready2019-10-23T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:27:49ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 4Push for properties to be fire ready

Firefighters are urging landowners to clean up their properties ahead of what is -expected to be a dry and -hotter-than-average summer.

Forest Fire Management's Michael Harper said conditions meant it was possible Victoria could face horror bushfires similar to those that engulfed New South Wales and Queensland in September.

"We've seen some good grass growth cross the region and that growth will really take off now with the sunlight," Mr Harper said.

"We'd expect some high fuel loads across the region." The state has hired 30 seasonal forest firefighters to bring the force's total number to 150 from -November. A fleet of 38 specialised firefighting vehicles will be available for -emergencies over summer, including numerous fire tankers and earthmoving machinery.

Mr Harper said the waterbombing helicopter Sikorsky S6, with a water-carrying -capacity of 3000 litres, would arrive at Colac air base in the coming months and would be on call for fires across the Otway district.

Country Fire Authority deputy chief officer Rohan Luke said while firefighters were doing all they could to prepare for the fire season residents must also play their part.

"While emergency services are ready for all types of -emergencies that may arise this summer, it is important that local residents also prepare themselves, their families and their properties for the bushfire risk this summer," Mr Luke said.He said tomorrow, with a forecast of 32C, would be the first true test for firefighters.

fire nears</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">LA THREAT</p><p nitf:lede="true">More than 3000 firefighters were today battling a wildfire roaring over a 6800ha swath of suburban Los Angeles, forcing hundreds of people to flee their homes.</p><p nitf:lede="true">The blaze, which erupted yesterday, has razed at least one house and ripped through another four buildings in the northwestern suburbs of the second-largest US city.</p><p>"At this time 17,000 acres have been burned," Los Angeles County supervisor Zev Yaroslavsky said.</p><p>The cause of the blaze, which was just 5 per cent contained, was under investigation.</p><p>Officials of LA and neighbouring Ventura counties would declare parts of the fire-stricken zones disaster areas in order to unblock emergency funds to help fight the blaze and house evacuees, he said.</p><p>"It is a very serious fire," Jim Wells of the LA fire brigade said.</p><p>Several hundred evacuees had fled their homes as the 16km wall of flames marched across the area, Wells said.</p><p>Residents of parts of the suburbs of Chatsworth, Oak Park, Box Canyon, Woolsey Canyon, Bell Canyon, Lake Manor and Old Agoura have evacuated.</p><p>The fire erupted near the San Fernando Valley suburb of Chatsworth, which lies about 50km northwest of downtown LA and is home to the world's largest pornographic industry.</p><p>The inferno spread quickly as high temperatures and winds fanned it through tinder-dry undergrowth left over by torrential rainfalls early this year, and sent a huge pall of black smoke into the air.</p><p>Firefighters were frantically chopping fire breaks across the area to halt the advance of the flames, as 11 helicopters and aircraft dumped water and fire retardant.</p><p>A lull in the winds gave firefighters a much-needed break in the latest chapter of their annual battle against the flames.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier urn:contentItem:5MW1-93M1-F0J6-J341-00000-00Special branch seeks burly bandits2017-02-14T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:27:49ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 10Special branch seeks burly banditsDarren Gray

The thieves had no need to tip-toe around. And they certainly didn't operate in silence. In fact, one of the key tools they used was a chainsaw.

It is believed the thieves in question travelled more than 20 kilometres along bush tracks in the forest near Jamieson some time around Christmas and New Year, looking for trees they could rob.

And when they found suitable trees, they stripped them of the valuable "burls" - or knobs - bulging from the side of their trunks.

Workers from Forest Fire Management Victoria have discovered more than 50 trees have been damaged by the loppers, who cut more than 100 burls from native trees in the Upper Goulburn State Forest.

The burls contain "figured" wood, can sometimes weigh more than 100 kilograms, and are considered valuable pieces of timber by woodworkers who make hand-crafted items that can sell for hundreds of dollars.

The thieves took so much stuff from the forest they probably worked for at least a day, filling a ute or a trailer with their plunder. Forest Fire Management Victoria's local district manager Lucas Russell said those behind the theft had gone to "considerable effort" to remove the burls.

Mr Russell warned that the damage to the trees could have serious environmental consequences. "The illegal removal of the burls could seriously damage the trees and impact on habitat for the native animals."

urn:contentItem:44DX-H7B0-015H-9546-00000-00<published>2001-01-03T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T08:27:49Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>LOCAL; Pg. 11</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>Forest fire closes Renison Bell mine</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:byline>DANNY ROSE, ELLEN WHINNETT</nitf:byline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">THE Renison Bell tin mine was closed down yesterday after a bushfire swept through the West Coast mining lease.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> Fierce winds and temperatures into the 30s saw the fire take hold in thick forest near Zeehan.</p><p>The mine was shut down and more than 170 staff and underground workers were evacuated to emergency meeting points.</p><p> Worker Ray Challenger, who manned the phones in the emergency control room, said emergency procedures were enacted because of the risk of smoke inhalation, both above ground and below through ventilation shafts.</p><p> The fire was first noticed about 2.40pm yesterday near the mine's tailings dam.</p><p> A spotter plane was sent up to give more accurate information on the fire's movements.</p><p> The column of smoke could be seen from several kilometres away. Tourists stopped on the Murchison Highway to take videos of the dense smoke enveloping the mine buildings.</p><p> Late yesterday, firefighters from Rosebery, Zeehan and Queenstown were fighting the blaze, along with the Renison Bell firefighting team and crews from ForestryTasmania.</p><p> While it is not burning on ForestryTasmania land, it does have large tracts of plantations in the area.</p><p> Last night, the fire was believed to have turned away from the mine.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata Stricken yachtsman Can't begin to imagine. Hope he is well looked after in Eden, it's such a beautiful place.

Fay Scetrine

Epic effort!

Isabel Robinson

Mallacoota bushfire prep There are also a lot of individual property owners scattered in the bush everywhere from Eden to the border. Janet Sharp

As in Pambula Beach and Wonboyn Lake. There are lots of small towns/villages the have only one road in and out.

Annabelle Hyde

More fuel reduction burns ... the bush is thicker/denser than it ever has been and little has been done to reduce fuel loads! I believe cool winter burns should be used instead of waiting to do hot burns which are invariably stopped by adverse weather conditions. Back to traditional methods. They were successful for a long time!

Steve Casement

Then if that is the case you're going to need a bigger boat.

Mark Dickinson

We were there years ago when there were bush fires all around east Vic. It was so scary.

Karen Perry

Eden kids build skate ramp Such a beautiful campus, and innovative educators. Lucky kids!

Buff Hungerland

Pericoe pine forest fire Thank you - I've been worrying about this fire breaking the containment lines. The winds from the SW would drive it towards my place, perhaps on to Pambula. Three cheers for the firies, modern day superheroes.

Isabel Robinson

urn:contentItem:5R7W-G5V1-DY19-C0K5-00000-00Fire crews controlling fire at Corin Dam2017-12-24T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:27:49ZLexisNexisFire crews controlling fire at Corin Dam

Firefighters are at the scene of a forest fire near the Corin Dam wall in Canberra's Namadgi National Park.

Firefighters are at the scene of a forest fire near the Corin Dam wall in Canberra's Namadgi National Park.

On Sunday afternoon, the Emergency Services Agency said 10 units were fighting the blaze, which was burning at a slow rate in a south east direction.

By 4.15pm, crews had set up control lines around the fire and contained the blaze.

They will remain at the scene for several hours.

The ESA advised people to monitor the situation closely via the media and the ESA website.

urn:contentItem:5RWF-R2R1-F0J6-J53K-00000-00Mine2018-03-17T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:27:49ZLexisNexisSATURDAYPg. 6MineAdam Holmes

FOR more than two years, Robert Brown has used hand tools to dig a mine shaft in public bushland at the end of a dead end track north of Dunolly.

The 61-year-old prospector dug his mine 20 feet below the surface, and constructed an underground drive 30 feet across, where he was looking for gold to supplement his disability support pension.

His mine had bunting, pickets and protective mesh, similar to safety measures at other protected mine shafts in the area. He was at the site several times a week, except in winter.

The lack of a big haul of gold did not bother him - it was more of a hobby.

So when he arrived at the site on Sunday, February 25, to find it completely filled in by officers from Forest Fire Management Victoria, he was furious.

"Unless somebody physically climbed down there and checked, they would have had no idea if anyone was working down there," Mr Brown said.

"They've destroyed two to three years of hard work, my hobby.

"If they filled it in and you were down there, you'd be dead."

Mr Brown claims he was operating under the miners right, which he believes allows for excavation using hand tools.

His tools are now buried under tonnes of dirt at the bottom of the mine.

The Prospectors and Miners Association of Victoria has supported Mr Brown in his attempt to get an explanation from the department and compensation for the loss of tools, labour and the hardship he suffered.

A number of meetings were held in relation to the matter and several hundred dollars in compensation was offered to replace the lost tools. Mr Brown said the loss of tools was a minor matter, and he was more concerned with the loss of his years' of work.

Forest Fire Management Victoria claims it attempted to contact Mr Brown "more than a dozen times" over two years without success, and it was aware of the mineshaft since 2015.

District manager Paul Bates said the mine was filled in preparation for a controlled burn in the area.

"The mine shaft is located within a planned burn area scheduled to be carried out this autumn and a decision was made to fill the open shaft for the safety of firefighters," he said.

urn:contentItem:5XHH-88X1-F0JP-W3D6-00000-00State tight-lipped on fuel load risks2019-11-16T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:27:49ZLexisNexisGOSSIPPg. 9State tight-lipped on fuel load risksANDREW KOUBARIDIS

DATA that shows the danger caused by fuel loads in Victorian bushfire zones is being withheld by the State Government.

Despite fears of a catastrophic fire season, country Victorians are in the dark about the fine fuel loads that have built up in forests around their communities.

Fine fuels are dead plant material.

The East Central fire zone, where Black Saturday claimed 173 lives in 2009, is the only area to have data released - and levels there have reached extreme.

The Government has -declined to release data for the rest of the state. A Government spokeswoman said: "We act on the advice of fire experts who've -advised the map shouldn't be released at this time." One of the leaders of the response to the 2009 disaster has slammed the government secrecy.

Ewan Waller, the state's former forest fire chief, and head of the then Department of Sustainability and Environment, said the Government had to be accountable for what was happening in bushland, so people were aware of the danger.

"It's about having a simple measurement of how we are doing on fuel measurement and saying to the community, 'this is where we are at and we are working to a plan'," Mr Waller said.

He was in favour of a scorecard where people could monitor the changes.Opposition emergency services spokesman Brad Battin said the Government was not releasing the data because "it would show how little (it) has done to prepare public land".

urn:contentItem:5XT6-T8D1-F0J6-J2Y2-00000-00Volunteers working tirelessly to have Christmas off with family2019-12-23T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:27:49ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 3Volunteers working tirelessly to have Christmas off with familySAM RIGNEY

FIRE crews battling the northern edge of the Gospers Mountain mega blaze - the largest single ignition point forest fire in Australia's history - are racing against the clock to shore up containment lines in remote and difficult terrain so exhausted volunteers can have Christmas Day off to spend with their families.

The Gospers Mountain monster was sparked by a lightning strike in Wollemi National Park on October 26 and has since burnt through an area of bush seven times the size of Singapore.

The blaze spread further south on Saturday in horrendously hot and windy conditions, with homes damaged or destroyed at Bilpin and Lithgow. On the northern end of the fire in the Hunter, the fire broke containment lines on Saturday at Putty Valley and crews were forced to undertake property protection.

With conditions more favourable on Sunday, crews were heading to remote and difficult terrain in Putty Valley to attempt to shore up containment lines.

"We've got some pretty difficult challenges ahead," Hunter Incident Management Team public liaison officer Leanne Bell said.

"Some of these fires are in really remote or difficult terrain. Down really steep escarpments into the valley and trying to get containment lines around that is really difficult. "We're trying to get everything done and consolidated by Christmas day so that the volunteers can have a day off."

Meanwhile, the Kerry Ridge fire, which started in the Muswellbrook area, made a "significant run to the east" on Saturday, crossing transition lines and burning across the northern part of Putty before the wind changed late in the day.

urn:contentItem:5R32-T1G1-JD34-V073-00000-00Firefighter training and preparedness2017-12-02T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:27:49ZLexisNexisFirefighter training and preparedness

Forest Fire Management Victoria firefighting recruits are being put through their paces this week at a training camp in Licola, 50 kilometres north of Heyfield.

Assistant Chief Fire officer, Chris Stephenson said: "This year, we have our usual 174 Project Firefighters, (PFFs), plus an additional 35 for this season, boosting our total to 209 forest firefighters for Gippsland."

"There are also 17 new Forest Fire Operations roles across the region."

"During the week-long camp, the PFFs will cover topics including emergency management procedures, safety and survival techniques, fire suppression techniques and planned burning."

"The comprehensive training course ensures our teams are trained to the highest levels in fighting fires and reducing bushfire risk."

"The mix of classroom theory and field-based activities helps prepare our staff for the demands of the fire ground and the varied role of a firefighter. They will also get to meet and work alongside experienced firefighters and gain an understanding of what it's like on the fire line."

"At the completion of the camps, the PFFs will return to their work centres to undertake additional training and accreditation, including four-wheel driving and dangerous tree management."

"They will then assist our permanent crews to undertake priority works including fire suppression, planned burning, track clearing and slashing."

"They will also be available for deployment both within the Gippsland region and across the state, depending on the severity of the season."

"All our staff have an emergency response role as well as their usual job. This can be anything from a firefighter, to catering officer, planning officer, public information officer, incident controller, operations officer, staging area manager, airbase manager and many more - we all have a part to play when it comes to any emergency incident."

"In Gippsland, we have four fixed-wing bombers in place due to the recent bushfires, plus a light helicopter. There will be another two helicopters based at Heyfield and the Latrobe Valley airbase and another fixed-wing reconnaissance aircraft at Latrobe Valley."

"And on the ground we have 88 specialist firefighting 4WD vehicles (or ultralight tankers), 14 dozers and 15 heavy tankers ready to support our crews in fire management and suppression."

urn:contentItem:5R15-2HC1-F0J6-J17C-00000-00Weather conditions are changing quickly2017-11-23T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:27:49ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 3Weather conditions are changing quickly

A leading Ballarat firefighter says most weather forecasts point to a fierce fire season across the region.

Recent rainfall has been sporadic, with many areas receiving little or no rain despite thunderstorms causing flash flooding in Ballarat's CBD last weekend.

CFA operations manager Brett Boatman this week said it was important to prepare a property to minimise any chance of fire taking hold or spreading.

"It is important to undertake mitigation work, including slashing, grading and general property clean-ups before the fire danger ratings increase," he said.

"Any burning off requires thorough planning, ensuring there are enough people to monitor, contain and extinguish the burn safely and effectively.

"Avoid burning off when high winds are forecast, not only on the day of your burn, but for the days afterwards."

Mr Boatman said the CFA took a zero tolerance approach to any unauthorised fires.

"A fire started at any time of the year, which damages someone else's property, is a crime," he said.

"For information about burn-off restrictions specific to your area consult your local council.

"Even if you have a permit to use fire over the fire danger period, make sure you read the conditions carefully.

"Failing to follow just one of those conditions may leave you open to prosecution."

The warning comes after more than 25 Forest Fire Management Victoria recruits travelled to Beaufort this week for firefighting training.

Held at the Cave Hill Creek Camp northwest of the town, the training included lessons on understanding fire behaviour and working around aircraft.

"Forest Fire Management Victoria firefighting teams, working together with the CFA and other land managers, help to reduce the risk of fire, containing outbreaks and managing environmental impacts in Victoria's parks, forests and other public as well as private land," Grampians regional manager Peter Kambouris said.

"In the lead up to summer, people should increase their understanding of the fire risk where they live, prepare their property, and talk to their household about what they will do to stay safe."

For more information on how landholders should be prepared in the Ballarat region ahead of the fire danger period, head to emergency.vic.gov.au

urn:contentItem:5XCF-12G1-F0J6-J086-00000-00Smoke likely during 115-hectare burn2019-10-26T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:27:49ZLexisNexisSmoke likely during 115-hectare burn

SMOKE may be visible in Bendigo for a week after a burn planned for Eaglehawk's Lightning Hill on Sunday and Monday.

Forest Fire Management Victoria and the Country Fire Authority have told the community they will burn 115-hectares to reduce fuel loads.

The burn will take place 1.5 kilometres north of Eaglehawk in the Bendigo Regional Park on Sunday October 27 and Monday October 28, weather permitting.

Read more: Outlook points to a potentially long and dangerous bushfire season

The burn should be completed by 8pm on Wednesday October 30, but smoke may be visible until November 3.

If you experience any symptoms that may be due to smoke exposure you should get medical advice or call Nurse on Call on 1300 606 024.

Those nearby should close windows and doors to prevent smoke from entering.

Read more: Low rainfall leaves forests dry and open to fire risk

Low visibility from smoke can make roads hazardous. Drivers should obey all traffic signs and instructions from fire agency crews near the burn.

Anyone planning to access parks should be aware of burns planned for the area and stay away from areas that have been burnt recently.

Access to walking tracks, car parks, camping grounds and picnic sites in the areas near the burn may be restricted.

Find out more at: plannedburns.ffm.vic.gov.au/

urn:contentItem:5XBH-84N1-F0J6-J3PM-00000-00Goonoo Forest bushfire will keep burning during night: RFS2019-10-24T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:27:49ZLexisNexisGoonoo Forest bushfire will keep burning during night: RFSNadine Morton

FIREFIGHTERS might have been battling the 263 hectare bushfire burning in the Goonoo Forest since Tuesday morning, but it is yet to be brought under control.

Hot and dry conditions have helped fuel the blaze and create spot fires, while the wattle vegetation being burnt contains high oil levels which is creating dark columns of smoke.

NSW Rural Fire Service (RFS) Inspector Ben Shepherd said at 4.30pm on Wednesday the fire was at advice level and was 'being controlled'.

READ MORE: See the large air tanker in action above the Goonoo Forest fire

"There have been a number of spot fires this afternoon [Wednesday], but the crews have been able to contain them quite quickly," he said. "The large air tanker is being used to lay down some retardant lines [to help contain the blaze]."

There are 35 firefighters on scene, along with five aerial appliances.

Inspector Shepherd said while the dark smoke, which is visible from some distance away, has left some residents concerned the fire is burning well within the forest and not near any properties.

Mendooran Road, between Mogriguy Road and Castlereagh Highway, is closed in both directions.

READ ALSO: Dubbo man jailed after he stabbed another man three times

The bushfire is currently burning within the areas between Mendooran, Frost, Frazers and Garlings roads.

urn:contentItem:7V1B-7980-YBDY-R00X-00000-00Outcry as downed power lines blamed for forest fire2009-02-16T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:27:49ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 12Outcry as downed power lines blamed for forest fire

POWER supplier SP Ausnet says it will co-operate fully with any investigations into the cause of the Victorian bushfires.

Angry Kinglake residents are launching a class action in the Victorian Supreme Court against SP Ausnet and the State Government, arguing a 2km stretch of downed power lines sparked and set fire to a nearby pine forest.

``We stand ready to assist the relevant authorities with their inquiries if it is necessary for us to do so now and in the coming months,'' SP Ausnet spokeswoman Louisa Graham said.

She said the company's priority was restoring power to fire-affected areas as soon as possible.

Victorian federal MP Fran Bailey said the Country Fire Authority had told her one of the power lines had broken before the fire. ``It was whipping against the ground and sparked,'' she said. ``We've got to do better, deliver our power better.''

This was confirmed by a CFA volunteer, who asked not to be named, but said the first crews at the scene of the fire in Kilmore saw a fallen power line arcing.

Victorian Premier John Brumby refused to comment on the power line claim, saying it would be examined as part of the Royal Commission into the bushfires.

``No stone will be left unturned . . . The Royal Commission will, of course, look at all of the factors with the fires,'' Mr Brumby told reporters yesterday.

The Phoenix Taskforce, which is investigating the fires, is examining a 2km stretch of power line that collapsed a week ago on Saturday during the extreme heat, according to an interstate report.

Victoria Police Chief Commissioner Christine Nixon said authorities were still determining how the Kinglake bushfire started.

urn:contentItem:5N7F-XMD1-JD34-V23T-00000-00Fire danger season near, burns increase2017-04-04T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:27:49ZLexisNexisNEWSFire danger season near, burns increase

The city's chief fire officer has urged residents to ensure they register their burn-offs as the fire season comes to a close next week.

CFA district 15 operations manager Brett Boatman said the fire danger period would end at 1am on April 10 for residents in the Ballarat, Moorabool and Golden Plains council areas. The period will end for residents in the Hepburn region at 1am on April 17.

Mr Boatman said rainfall in early 2017 had resulted in a significant amount of vegetation growth which would translate into a lot of private burn offs in coming weeks.

He urged people to do the right thing by checking conditions and registering their burn-offs.

"Every year our brigades get more and more frustrated at the number of false alarm calls they have to respond to as a result of people not doing the right thing," he said.

"Calls to unregistered burn-offs take volunteer firefighters away from workplaces, families and potentially genuine emergencies."

Any calls to triple-0 about smoke in the air are cross-checked with the burn-off register. When nothing is registered firefighters must attend.

"So if you haven't registered your burn you can expect some disgruntled firies arriving at your property asking you to 'please explain'," Mr Boatman said.

Meanwhile, Forest Fire Management will conduct a number of fuel-reduction planned burns around Beaufort in coming weeks.

The first of these will be a 46 hectare burn along Elimination Track, 6 km north of Beaufort. Forest Fire Management Victoria's Midlands District Manager Jasmine Filmer said biodiversity officers would be monitoring the progress of the burn.

urn:contentItem:5XM8-TPR1-JD3N-50VD-00000-00Deadline looms for property clean-ups2019-11-30T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:27:49ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 7Deadline looms for property clean-upsOlivia Shying

LANDOWNERS have 10 days to clean up their properties -before fire restrictions begin early next month.

Fire restrictions will come into force across the City of Greater Geelong, Borough of Queenscliffe, Golden Plains Shire and Surf Coast on December 9.

CFA District 7 operations manager Mick McGuinness said while agencies were doing all they could to prepare for above normal bushfire activity the community must also play its part.

"We are seeing very dry soil in the Otways which means a dry bush area along the coast that will sustain significant fire," Mr McGuinness said.

"While CFA and its partner agencies Parks Victoria, Forest Fire Management, and Emergency Management Victoria are doing everything we can to prepare for the bushfire season, we look to the community to use common sense and take responsibility for preventing fires." The Seasonal Bushfire Outlook for Southern Australia has identified the possibility of normal bushfire activity with warmer days and nights ahead of severe fire danger days.

Mr McGuinness said a warm and dry outlook also carries some risk that ash forests in the central highlands and Otways may dry out faster and become more flammable than normal during summer.

"So far this year, out-of-control burn-offs and unregistered burn-offs have already caused unnecessary call-outs for brigades," Mr McGuinness said.

"You should not burn off when winds are high or high winds are forecast - not only on the day of your burn but for the days afterwards."Mr McGuinness said once the Fire Danger Period comes into effect, the CFA will have a zero-tolerance approach to fires caused by negligent behaviour and they will be investigated by police and the CFA.

urn:contentItem:4TY2-MBG0-TXX1-F0NG-00000-00Forest fire rips through wealthy enclave Rich flee flames2008-11-15T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:27:49ZLexisNexisWORLDPg. 40Forest fire rips through wealthy enclave Rich flee flamesUS Santa Barbara, Wed.

AN explosive wildfire destroyed about 70 homes, injured four people and forced thousands to flee in the ritzy southern California community of Montecito, a longtime hideaway for celebrities such as Oprah Winfrey and Rob Lowe.

The fire started about 6pm local time yesterday and quickly spread to about 325ha - destroying dozens of homes in less than five hours in the foothills of Montecito, just south-east of Santa Barbara.

Several fire departments were battling the flames as thick plumes of smoke hovered overhead.

Montecito fire spokeswoman Geri Ventura said she did not know exactly how many homes had burned but television footage showed flames engulfing dozens of large multimillion-dollar houses. Ventura said about a quarter of the community of 10,000 people was evacuated and more could be moved if the fire spreads.

The fire broke out shortly before 6pm local time and quickly spread through more than 120ha in the foothills 8km south of Santa Barbara.

Several fire departments were battling the flames as thick plumes of smoke hovered overhead.

``It looked like lava coming down a volcano,'' Leslie Hollis Lopez told The Associated Press as she gathered belongings from her house.

It was immediately not known whether any celebrities' homes had burned or whether anyone was injured.

One resident described the area as deserted.

``You can just hear the explosions . . . of vehicles, homes,'' Michaelo Rosso told KCAL-TV as he prepared to leave his home. ``It sounds like the Fourth of July out here.''

Santa Barbara County officials said about 125 engines and three water-dropping helicopters were en route or at the scene. Firefighters faced wind gusts as high as 113km/h.

urn:contentItem:5MW3-TCN1-DY19-C3M6-00000-00Copse and robbers: Burl bandits saw off trees' valuable gnarly knobs2017-02-13T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:27:49ZLexisNexisCopse and robbers: Burl bandits saw off trees' valuable gnarly knobsDarren Gray

More than 50 trees have been damaged by chainsaw-wielding crooks who cut more than 100 burls from native trees in the Upper Goulburn State Forest.

The thief had no need to tip-toe around. And they certainly didn't operate in silence. In fact, one of the key tools they used during their burst of dastardly behaviour was a chainsaw.

It is believed that the thief or thieves in question travelled more than 20 kilometres along bush tracks in the forest near Jamieson some time around Christmas and New Year, looking for trees they could rob.

And when they found suitable trees, they stripped them of the valuable "burls" - or knobs - bulging from the side of their trunks.

Forest workers from Forest Fire Management Victoria have discovered more than 50 trees have been damaged by the loppers, who cut more than 100 burls from native trees in the Upper Goulburn State Forest.

Burls are gnarly growths bulging from the side of trees. The burls contain "figured" wood, can sometimes weigh more than 100 kilograms, and are considered valuable pieces of timber by woodworkers who make hand-crafted items from them, like fruit bowls and on occasions, coffee tables.

The thieves took so much stuff from the forest that they probably worked for at least a day, filling a ute or a trailer with their plunder.

Forest Fire Management Victoria's local district manager, Lucas Russell, said the person behind the sting had gone to "considerable effort" to remove the burls.

"This is the worst case I've seen of systematic removal of burls over a broad bit of the landscape," he said.

"Where I've seen them illegally removed [in the past], it's usually one or two burls to make a particular item," he said.

Mr Russell urged people buying intricate woodwork pieces, especially online or via social media sale groups, to ensure the wood had come from sustainable sources.

The feature pieces made from burls, such as wooden bowls or sculptures, might sell for hundreds of dollars, he said.

Mr Russell also warned that the damage to the trees could have serious environmental consequences.

"The illegal removal of the burls has the potential to seriously damage the trees and impact on habitat for the native animals," he said.

"It does increase the risk of infection and disease, that could lead to death.

"So that is a concern to me, particularly some of the trees where they've removed five or six burls," he said.

Forest Fire Management Victoria has warned that it is an offence under the Forests Act 1958 to damage any tree, or to be in possession of any forest produce without having been authorised to remove it.

Those found guilty of such an offence could face a maximum fine of $7773, or 12 months' imprisonment.

Anyone with information about what happened in the forest is asked to call the department of environment Mansfield office on 5733 1200, or the Department of Environment, Land, Water and Planning customer service centre on 136 186.

urn:contentItem:5MWF-43G1-JD34-V2T4-00000-00Authority lashes out after illegal bush doof2017-02-16T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:27:49ZLexisNexisAuthority lashes out after illegal bush doofBrendan Wrigley

Forest Fire Management Victoria crew members were left unimpressed last week when they were forced to clean up after an illegal rave party in the Wombat State Forest close to Bullangarook.

Officers were forced to clean up a fire pit which was still alight, empty bottles, cans, small disco balls and even camp chairs.

The size of the fire far exceeded the one-metre diameter allowed for campfires.

The crew was forced to clean up 11 bags of garbage and also had to clean nearby bushland which had been used as a toilet.

Forest Fire Management Victoria Grampians forest and fire operations regional manager Peter Kambouris said the party was illegal and starting uncontrolled camp fires in summer put the wider community at risk.

"Anyone found to have organised such an event and/or leaving the site in poor condition can be subject to a range of on the spot fines and/or a prosecution in court," Mr Kambouris said.

"Leaving this particular camp fire in such a state was simply reckless; poor campfire practices such as this can put nearby communities at risk.

Persons or companies who are found to have conducted a recreational activity for profit on Crown land may risk being prosecuted in the Magistrates' Court and potentially face fines of $3109 for an individual and $15,546 for a company.

Meanwhile if prosecuted in court, the maximum penalty for littering is a fine of $6218, while the penalty for leaving campfires unattended can include fines of up to $15,546.

"We want people to enjoy themselves and the outdoors, but they must understand that using our forests and reserves at this time of year also comes with greater risk and responsibility to be bushfire safe," Mr Kambouris said.

urn:contentItem:58DN-9PF1-F0J6-J3JS-00000-00Hodgman playing with Tasmanian forest fire2013-05-15T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:27:49ZLexisNexisPg. 19Hodgman playing with Tasmanian forest fireBarry Prismall

A BRAVE but foolhardy Hodgman government next March would unscramble the forest settlement.

A demolition job may provide Will Hodgman with a major point of difference with Labor, but he does not need this pain to remain the election favourite.

In fact it may savage him, in a campaign where seats will be hard fought. Despite favourable polls the Liberals still have to overcome the combined vote of Labor and the Greens.

Consider a recent statement from Braddon Liberal MHA and wealthy businessman Adam Brooks: ``You can never appease Green groups who are driven to shut down job creating developments, in their endless quest to turn Tasmania into one great big national park."

Adam Brooks knows his electorate and the tough job of business, but his statement displays poor judgment and a party lagging behind the times.

The Libs ought to be able to spot pragmatism when they see it. The forest settlement appears to be a big win for Green groups, who put a 572,000-hectare ambit claim out there, and got almost 90 per cent.

However, battle cries from veterans like Peg Putt and Bob Brown are about as obsolete as Will Hodgman's vow to scrap the deal. The weakness in his critique is that the forest industry supports it, and will stand united with environmental groups like the Wilderness Society and Australian Conservation Foundation that also support it.

As former Coalition leader Andrew Peacock in the 1980s would tell Gordon-below-Franklin dam tragics _ a Coalition government would never revive the project because almost $300 million in compensation had been paid over. The same reasoning applies to today's settlement.

By the time of the next state election, all the current drama surrounding the forestry deal will be mere background noise. Tasmanians want to move on. The only diehards left squabbling will be Bob Brown, Peg Putt and Will Hodgman.

The old Greens diehards can do what they like, as relevancy deprivation slowly sets in, but Will Hodgman will have a new government to mould. The mammoth task facing any new government next March will be to show it can turn around the state's fortunes within four years. It will completely overshadow an old barnacle issue like forestry.

Some elections are watershed events _ when the reins of government change from a party in power for a long time to a new regime. You could include in this the Whitlam government in 1972, Bob Hawke in 1983 and John Howard's ascension in 1996. In Tasmania think of Robin Gray in 1982 and Jim Bacon in 1998. Each watershed victory was buoyed by phenomena like unification, newness, and refreshing change. The new government, like a new fashion, would start its first term with substantial community goodwill.

Imagine a new Hodgman government hurtling back to the future, into a divisive fight with a united conservation movement, when voters would want the economy to be front and centre.

What would be the point now, of the conservation movement and industry mending fences and rebuilding crucial overseas markets, when they know they could be back in the trenches fighting each other within a year, in Will Hodgman's nostalgic war.

Yes, the Libs will want to parade a state reopened for business, but, an all out war in the forests, with no help from sensible conservationists like Vica Bayley, of the Wilderness Society, to moderate the battleground, will send precisely the wrong signal to external investors.

This is why the Libs will ultimately back off from threats to dismantle the forest deal. They don't need the threat in order to win next March, and to persist with it would merely hand Premier Lara Giddings a nicely packaged election manifesto.
